abstract.p: College football report discusses outlook for weekend's key games; photo (S)

block.p: NO. 3 ALABAMA 0-0 at U.C.L.A. 0-0 Alabama, the Southeastern Conference's Western Division favorite, has talent to burn. Freddie Milons, its flanker/running back/trick-play quarterback, and Shaun Bohanon, its new tailback, will test U.C.L.A.'s improved defense. Alabama is favored, but U.C.L.A. could be tough.TV: CH7, 3:30 P.M.

NO. 22 SOUTHERN MISSISSIPPI 0-0 NO. 13at TENNESSEE 0-0 With sophomore Joey Mathews succeeding Tee Martin at quarterback, Tennessee is a division favorite in the Southeastern Conference. If Southern Mississippi survives openers at Tennessee and Alabama, it will be a national power. TV: ESPN, 7:30 P.M.

NO. 3 ALABAMA 0-0 at U.C.L.A. 0-0 Alabama, the Southeastern Conference's Western Division favorite, has talent to burn. Freddie Milons, its flanker/running back/trick-play quarterback, and Shaun Bohanon, its new tailback, will test U.C.L.A.'s improved defense. Alabama is favored, but U.C.L.A. could be tough.TV: CH7, 3:30 P.M.

NO. 22 SOUTHERN MISSISSIPPI 0-0 NO. 13at TENNESSEE 0-0 With sophomore Joey Mathews succeeding Tee Martin at quarterback, Tennessee is a division favorite in the Southeastern Conference. If Southern Mississippi survives openers at Tennessee and Alabama, it will be a national power. TV: ESPN, 7:30 P.M.

NO. 23 COLORADO 0-0 vs. COLORADO STATE (at Denver) 0-0 Colorado has the edge against a dangerous rival. It needs a good start because its next five opponents are Southern California, Washington, Kansas State, Texas A&M and Texas.TV: ESPN, 6 P.M.
OTHER GAMES
EAST Toledo (0-0) at Penn State (0-1) Penn State's defense is no longer overwhelming, and the Nittany Lions rushed for only 6 yards against Southern Cal. TV: ESPN2, Noon.
Villanova (0-0) at Rutgers (0-0) Rutgers, 1-10 last year, is worried about its offensive line.
Boston College (0-0) at West Virginia (0-0) Both teams are unhappy having to start the season with a Big East game. TV: ESPN, Noon.
SOUTH Tulane (0-0) at No. 18 Mississippi (0-0) Ole Miss can go a long way behind Deuce McAllister, a fast and punishing runner.
New Mexico State (0-0) at South Carolina (0-0) A chance for Lou Holtz to win a game at South Carolina after last year's 0-11 nightmare.
MIDWEST Louisiana Tech (0-0) at No. 8 Kansas State (1-0) Kansas State beat Iowa last weekend with a decent defense and a ragged offense.

No. 25 Texas A&M (0-0) at Notre Dame (0-0) Mark Farris, the Aggies' new quarterback, is 25, with five years of minor league baseball behind him. Notre Dame faces another testing season. TV: CH4, 1:00 P.M.
Army (0-0) at Cincinnati (0-0) On Monday, after 15 seasons of the wishbone, Army, which lived by the run, unveils a quick-pass offense.
SOUTHWEST Texas-El Paso (0-0) at No. 19 Oklahoma (0-0) Oklahoma has good passing, good defense and a friendly schedule except for Texas, Kansas State and Nebraska in a row in midseason.
FAR WEST Idaho (0-0) at No. 14 Washington (0-0) If Marques Tuiasosopo's passing holds up, Washington will survive despite a questionable defense.
MISMATCHES San Jose State (0-0) at No. 1 Nebraska (0-0) San Jose State, 3-7 last year, is a seven-touchdown underdog against the national-champion favorite. Is this game necessary?
Bowling Green (0-0) at No. 6 Michigan (0-0) John Navarre, a 6-6 sophomore, will be Michigan's quarterback because Drew Henson is out six weeks with a broken right foot.
Ball State (0-0) at No. 9 Florida (0-0) Florida hopes to uncover its customary game-breaking receivers.
Akron (0-0) at No. 11 Virginia Tech (0-0) Tech's scheduled opener against Georgia Tech last Sunday was wiped out by a lightning storm.
Central Michigan (0-0) at No. 15 Purdue (0-0) Drew Brees can pass, but when the opposition gets tough, will Purdue find a running game?
Buffalo (0-0) at Syracuse (0-0) Syracuse won't announce its quarterback until game time. It will probably be sophomore Troy Nunes.
Rankings by Associated Press. All times are Eastern.
